results.process_description:
In a healthcare facility, the patient scheduling process begins when a patient contacts the reception desk to book an appointment with a specialist. 
    The receptionist verifies the patient's information, including insurance details and medical history, 
    before checking the specialist's availability on the electronic health record (EHR) system. If a suitable time is found, 
    the appointment is set, and the patient is informed about pre-appointment procedures, such as fasting or medication adjustments. 
    Confirmation calls or texts are sent to the patient 24 hours before the appointment. If the patient needs to reschedule or cancel, 
    the receptionist updates the appointment in the system and offers alternative dates.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when the EHR system is slow or unresponsive, I maintain a manual logbook of specialist availability to quickly check open slots and reduce patient wait times.

assessment.explaination: Maintaining a manual logbook of specialist availability is directly related to the patient scheduling process, especially as a contingency when the EHR system is slow, ensuring continuous appointment booking.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Maintaining a manual logbook of specialist availability is directly related to the patient scheduling process, especially as a contingency when the EHR system is slow, ensuring continuous appointment booking.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when patients call with incomplete insurance information, I tentatively schedule appointments but flag these cases for follow-up to avoid losing potential bookings.

assessment.explaination: Tentatively scheduling appointments when insurance information is incomplete addresses a common issue in patient scheduling and helps avoid losing bookings, fitting squarely within the described process.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Tentatively scheduling appointments when insurance information is incomplete addresses a common issue in patient scheduling and helps avoid losing bookings, fitting squarely within the described process.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when multiple patients need appointments with the same specialist, I create a prioritized waiting list so I can call patients proactively if earlier slots free up.

assessment.explaination: Creating a prioritized waiting list to manage multiple appointment requests with the same specialist is relevant to managing specialist availability and scheduling efficiency in the healthcare domain.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Creating a prioritized waiting list to manage multiple appointment requests with the same specialist is relevant to managing specialist availability and scheduling efficiency in the healthcare domain.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when patients do not respond to confirmation texts or calls, I keep a shortlist of high-risk patients to personally follow up, improving attendance rates.

assessment.explaination: Following up personally with high-risk patients who do not respond to confirmation calls or texts supports improving attendance rates and aligns with the appointment confirmation steps in the process.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Following up personally with high-risk patients who do not respond to confirmation calls or texts supports improving attendance rates and aligns with the appointment confirmation steps in the process.

workarounds.text: As a receptionist, when patients request rescheduling outside office hours, I note their preferences in a shared spreadsheet so that scheduling can be updated promptly during business hours.

assessment.explaination: Using a shared spreadsheet to note rescheduling preferences outside office hours helps manage appointment changes effectively, contributing to patient scheduling continuity.

llm_judge_domain_relevance.assessment_explaination: Using a shared spreadsheet to note rescheduling preferences outside office hours helps manage appointment changes effectively, contributing to patient scheduling continuity.
